Tedster
I'm really curious to see who beleives in god for concrete reasons and who beleives in him by faith.

post_info.post_title: Do you beleive God is Real? Why?

thebootfitter

I'm really curious to see who beleives in god for concrete reasons and who beleives in him by faith.

 In reality, there are no concrete 'reasons' for believing in God. If you believe in God, you believe based on faith. There is no incontrovertible physical evidence anywhere to even suggest that God exists... unless you first believe through faith that God exists.
DangerousMann

"There is far more proof needed to reasonably believe what's asserted in the Bible than there are for most things. "Extraordinary claims require extraordinary evidence" - Carl Sagan. I think that statement really is true. Just imagine a couple statements I could make and what the proper reactions should be to them.
 
 
 
 1. I was sitting in my room last night and I got a call from a friend of mine.
 
 The normal response is "ok". Everybody has phones, most people have friends, people calling their friends is a very normal thing to do... if this is the only statement I make about that call, there's really no reason for anybody to question the validity of it.
 
 
 2. I was sitting in my room last night, and a stranger wearing a black trenchcoat came and knocked on my door.
 
 This statement should be questioned somewhat. A person wearing a black trenchcoat during the summer in Florida is odd, but not the craziest thing anyone's ever seen probably... it does need to be explained though.. more detail is needed to conclude that this probably did happen. I should be able to explain the reason this happened adequately for somebody to believe that this actually happened.
 
 3. Last night I was sitting in my room and the walls started bleeding, then several of our founding fathers' ghosts walked out of my closet and told me it was my mission to make sure that church and state remain seperate.
 
 Everyone that hears me say that, should automatically say "no", until I provide some amazing, concrete proof of that. We know about the physical makeup of my bedroom walls, they can't bleed. The idea of ghosts from the past coming to visit people I would imagine is 100% foreign to just about everyone... so nobody's word should be taken on that either.
 
 
 
 This is the problem with the resurrection and miracles of Jesus... believers think we should believe it's true and just give it the kind of inspection like in number 1 or maybe number 2, but they're things that nobody living today has actually witnessed anything similar to... it defies the laws of science and nature to the extent that we know them... and the closest evidence we have of them is a couple eye-witness accounts (questionably), which weren't even written within 15 years of his death. There is no rational basis for believing it based on this... ANY feasible explanation that falls within the realm of reason and nature should ALWAYS be taken over any explanation which turns to the supernatural and irrational."
 
 -mD
Big Orn

I think that statement really is true. Just imagine a couple statements I could make and what the proper reactions should be to them.
 
 
 
 1. I was sitting in my room last night and I got a call from a friend of mine.
 
 The normal response is "ok". Everybody has phones, most people have friends, people calling their friends is a very normal thing to do... if this is the only statement I make about that call, there's really no reason for anybody to question the validity of it.

 This statement should be questioned somewhat. A person wearing a black trenchcoat during the summer in Florida is odd, but not the craziest thing anyone's ever seen probably... it does need to be explained though.. more detail is needed to conclude that this probably did happen. I should be able to explain the reason this happened adequately for somebody to believe that this actually happened.
 
 3. Last night I was sitting in my room and the walls started bleeding, then several of our founding fathers' ghosts walked out of my closet and told me it was my mission to make sure that church and state remain seperate.
 
 Everyone that hears me say that, should automatically say "no", until I provide some amazing, concrete proof of that. We know about the physical makeup of my bedroom walls, they can't bleed. The idea of ghosts from the past coming to visit people I would imagine is 100% foreign to just about everyone... so nobody's word should be taken on that either.
 
 
 
 This is the problem with the resurrection and miracles of Jesus... believers think we should believe it's true and just give it the kind of inspection like in number 1 or maybe number 2, but they're things that nobody living today has actually witnessed anything similar to... it defies the laws of science and nature to the extent that we know them... and the closest evidence we have of them is a couple eye-witness accounts (questionably), which weren't even written within 15 years of his death. There is no rational basis for believing it based on this... ANY feasible explanation that falls within the realm of reason and nature should ALWAYS be taken over any explanation which turns to the supernatural and irrational."

 Well, I suppose that the reply it took me almost 5 minutes to type, a couple more to check and a couple to correct will not suffice now.
epaphras_faith

Hello again everyone:
 
 I have been missing from the board for awhile. I hope to post more regularly but you never know. I say this as a precursor as you may not be able to debate me directly. I will give as much info as possible.
 
 Two things:
 
 1) There is evidence to SUGGEST that God exists.
 
 2) There is no PROOF.
 
 The evidence to suggest is in the lives of those who truly believe. Who's lives have been changed by God. I would say I am one of those. There is also evidence that is more circumstantial that many apologists would be familiar with. I am not an apologist but I will offer a few that I know of. Perhaps others better informed could offer more.
 
 The bible provides some evidence. It was written by the hands of many over a very long period of time with a remarkably consistent theme. That is that faith in God provides for an eternal life with him, and a lack of faith results in an eternal death apart from him.
 
 The earliest christians (those that likely knew Jesus or those that knew the apostles) died horrible and amazing deaths. If this were a known hoax (the ressurrection in particular) then they would have likely recanted, all of them. Yet several Romans write of the remarkable tenacity of the followers of Jesus. Pliny in particular.
 
 Again, this is evidence only to suggest not prove. I cannot prove nor can anyone else. However, to say that there is no evidence even to suggest it is way beyond the realm of logic.
 
 Thanks for hearing my 2 cents.
Big Orn

Okay, everyone. This post can live or die with this recommendation:
 
 Tedster - if you will, please, when starting a debate about a belief, please do not include the word concrete. Even if you are talking about the driveway. Okay?
 
 DangerousMann - When a thread starts with "Belief" in something, please don't bust bubbles by stating what needs to happen in order to prove something. Okay?
 
 Now.
 
 And thanks for your cooperation.
 
 <Big Orn sighs…<
Tedster

Okay, everyone. This post can live or die with this recommendation:
 
 Tedster - if you will, please, when starting a debate about a belief, please do not include the word concrete. Even if you are talking about the driveway. Okay?
 
 
 <Big Orn sighs...<

 My, appologies Orn, won't happen again.
thebootfitter

Again, this is evidence only to suggest not prove. I cannot prove nor can anyone else. However, to say that there is no evidence even to suggest it is way beyond the realm of logic.

 If you wrote this in response to my post, please note that I said that there is no PHYSICAL evidence that suggests that God exists without the mindset that God exists.
 
 Individuals who believe that God exists do not constitute physical evidence of God's existence. Their belief in God is the reason for their seemingly amazing actions. Their belief is in their mind (and/or their 'spirit'). It is based on faith. It is not based on physical evidence in reality.
 
 The Bible is a book. It was written by human beings (allegedly inspired by God). What is written in the Bible are ideas that were in existence prior to being written down, or they could not have been written down. If there is a central theme of ideas for a segment of the population over a long period of time, the population will be able to continue to write of those similar ideas with great consistency. That still does not constitute physical evidence in reality that God exists. That is just evidence that a similar belief in God has existed over a 'long' period of time by a segment of the population.
Valthonis

Would it be classified as beleiving in a god to just beleive a higher being exists in general? Also, one guy was argueing with me and told me that when god created man, that it didn't state anything about neandrethals but they do exist. He said that god created neandrethals along with man. Can anyone tell me how he can infer this when the bible just states Man
 
 If that doesn't make sense, please tell me
Big Orn

Would it be classified as beleiving in a god to just beleive a higher being exists in general? Also, one guy was argueing with me and told me that when god created man, that it didn't state anything about neandrethals but they do exist. He said that god created neandrethals along with man. Can anyone tell me how he can infer this when the bible just states Man
 
 If that doesn't make sense, please tell me

 He may be referring to the difference between Genesis 1: 26 – 28 where the Bible stated that God created mankind with His spoken word like He created the other creatures and told them to go all over the earth and subdue it. I can understand this as being separate beings. These were not human beings as we are, these were the inhabitants he spoke into existence. Were they cavemen/Neanderthals? I don’t know. I haven’t found enough written proof of that yet.
 In the second chapter God “forms” man from the dust of the earth and breathes Life into him. He then takes a rib from man and makes woman. He also makes them a special place called Eden where they can live forever – if they do as He says. See the difference from what he tells mankind in Chapter 1 ( go all over the earth) to what he gives Adam and Eve (Eden – one place to live) in Chapter 2?
 
 I hope this makes the cloud a little less dense.
Valthonis

He may be referring to the difference between Genesis 1: 26 – 28 where the Bible stated that God created mankind with His spoken word like He created the other creatures and told them to go all over the earth and subdue it. I can understand this as being separate beings. These were not human beings as we are, these were the inhabitants he spoke into existence. Were they cavemen/Neanderthals? I don’t know. He also makes them a special place called Eden where they can live forever – if they do as He says. See the difference from what he tells mankind in Chapter 1 ( go all over the earth) to what he gives Adam and Eve (Eden – one place to live) in Chapter 2?
 
 I hope this makes the cloud a little less dense.

 Thank you.
epaphras_faith

If you wrote this in response to my post, please note that I said that there is no PHYSICAL evidence that suggests that God exists without the mindset that God exists.
 
 Individuals who believe that God exists do not constitute physical evidence of God's existence. Their belief in God is the reason for their seemingly amazing actions. Their belief is in their mind (and/or their 'spirit'). It is based on faith. It is not based on physical evidence in reality.
 
 The Bible is a book. It was written by human beings (allegedly inspired by God). What is written in the Bible are ideas that were in existence prior to being written down, or they could not have been written down. If there is a central theme of ideas for a segment of the population over a long period of time, the population will be able to continue to write of those similar ideas with great consistency. That still does not constitute physical evidence in reality that God exists. That is just evidence that a similar belief in God has existed over a 'long' period of time by a segment of the population.

 
 I did not post directly in response to you although some of what you said is in there. I did respond to the question, mostly.
 
 Your argument that a central theme over time can be followed is very innaccurate. People are people and by nature will glorify themselves or attempt to. If there were not an intervening God then the books of the bible would go in all variety of directions. In particular the Gospels but the bible as a whole, do not show God's people from "their best side" as it were. 
 
 The people of God we see are flawed and demanding and condescending and crude, and even downright mean. However, the bible also shows a great deal of dependence on God for their righteousness. 
 
 You are quite correct that there is precious little PHYSICAL evidence to prove the reality of God. I do think there is evidence to suggest it. Suggestion is just that, suggestion. It does not require a preponderance of the evidence at all. 
 
 Belief truly is belief and not evidence based. You are correct there as well. I do think there is plenty of reason to believe in God. Where things often go awry is whether or not there is reason to believe, specifically, in one of the many gods discussed in the many religions. They are very different although many will argue for the commanalities, the differences are still quite significant. Christianity, for instance, is the only religion that declares a person justified and sanctified, and glorified purely as gifts of God. All others demand some kind of performance from the individual to acquire "enlightenment", "heaven" or other alternate realities. 
 
 As I said I do not think I was responding specifically to you but an overall response as I have been away from the board for a while and was having to insert again slowly and generally.
 
 Thanks for the discussion though.
thebootfitter

People are people and by nature will glorify themselves or attempt to.

 This is an assumption you are making, and it is your opinion. There is no evidence I am aware of that indicates what IS or ISN'T an essential part of human nature. But if you have evidence that suggests that human nature dictates that humans 'will glorify themselves or attempt to...' please, do share it.
 
 
You are quite correct that there is precious little PHYSICAL evidence to prove the reality of God. I do think there is evidence to suggest it. Suggestion is just that, suggestion. It does not require a preponderance of the evidence at all. 

 You misquote me here. I said that there is NO physical evidence... not 'precious little.' Any evidence that exists can only suggest that God exists if there is a pre-disposition to believe that God exists. If you are asserting that the evidence, by itself, can suggest that God exists, then share with me the evidence of which you speak.
 
 
I do think there is plenty of reason to believe in God.

 In reality, there are no 'reasons' to believe in God. Any 'reason' that you have for believing in God is made up in your mind. I believe in God. Why? Because I believe in God. I could list many reasons why I decide to believe in God, but they would simply be reasons to justify my belief. I do not need to justify my belief. I believe because I believe. Share with me what reasons you have for believing in God, and you will begin to see that your 'reasons' are fabricated by you.
sglaine

I think religion as a whole has gone to the dogs you now have in place in politics. I feel it do,es not belong there you have born again sprout up like weeds and they seem to focus on how people should live they want everybody to live by there standards. I'm sorry but you have multiple cultures and different views and beliefs. And they do not like how others live I also feel that they are losing reality with god. I like the old church better. I like how people acted in the old days. They had more spirit & class. I am starting to think that a lot of religion is a big farce. Back in the 60s and the 70s we did not hear about Born agains were we live. Don't get me wrong I do believe in god but the way I was brought up.And I am not an athiest
Lily

Hmm. What do I believe? I believe that there's no way that God can't exist. In theory, there has to be one immortal Creator of superior intelligence. I could go into it, but I'll spare you the details. Just because I'm Christian, doesn't mean I have to hate you and lecture you on why Christianity is the One True Way and there is no other religion and this is really getting to be a run-on so I guess I'll just stop now.
thebootfitter

...so I guess I'll just stop now.

 Thank you! Whew... :p 
 
 
In theory, there has to be one immortal Creator of superior intelligence. I could go into it, but I'll spare you the details.

 There HAS to be? Hmm... I don't think so. Why don't you go into it and spare us no details.
 
 
...why Christianity is the One True Way and there is no other religion...

 You believe that Christianity is the 'One True Way.' And if it is... then it is. But your belief does not make it so. You believe Christianity is the one true way to live with God forever in heaven. However, this belief has underlying assumptions which are also beliefs, one of which is the assumption that God even exists. And if God exists, that God is like the God described in the Bible.
 
 These are things that can only be accepted through faith. It is not possible to KNOW these things... only to BELIEVE.
prayforsurf0

In reality, there are no concrete 'reasons' for believing in God. If you believe in God, you believe based on faith. There is no incontrovertible physical evidence anywhere to even suggest that God exists... unless you first believe through faith that God exists.

 
 This statement is wrong. People from hundreds of years before Jesus was born prophesied that a baby would be born, in Bethlehem, of a virgin. There were over 50 more prophesies that were made about his life, and the sacrafice he made to pay for the sins of man, and the bigest one of all...He completely fufilled scripture when he rose from the dead. These men were inspired by Jesus, God, how can you argue that he is not the christ? The odds of one man filling all the prophesies is impossible. And these scriptures have been unchanged for the past 2000-2500 approx years! Thats proof for me that Jesus existed and that he is God. PM me if you like.
thebootfitter

This statement is wrong... Thats proof for me that Jesus existed and that he is God... 

 Your penultimate sentence sums this up well with the emphasis that I added. What you describe is sufficient 'proof' for you to believe. Why? Because you believe. Other than the Bible (which is far from being an accurate historical textbook) from where do you obtain the evidence of these prophets and their prophecies? 
 
 I am not discussing the God/Person of Jesus specifically. I am not discussing whether or not Jesus is the Son of God, who rose from the dead in atonement for our sins and the sins of the whole world. (Which, incidentally, I believe.) I am discussing the God of the Hebrews (or any other god for that matter). To believe the prophesies of which you speak, one must have faith. To believe that Jesus actually rose from the dead and ascended into heaven, one must have faith. There is no physical evidence that I am aware of to indicate that it did happen the way the Bible said it happened... except for in writings of human beings allegedly inspired by God. It takes faith to believe that those human beings were inspired by God. It takes faith to believe that what they describe actually happened the way they describe it.
 
 What I can say with certainty that cannot be disputed as far as I'm aware, is that whatever happened... happened. If a woman named Mary was impregnated by the Holy Spirit and conceived a child that she named Jesus who was crucified, died and buried, only to come back to life three days later and ascend into heaven after 40 days... then that's what happened. I believe that's what happened, but there's no physical evidence to prove that's actually what happened. It takes faith to believe.
 
 
And these scriptures have been unchanged for the past 2000-2500 approx years!

 Define "unchanged."
Valthonis

This statement is wrong. People from hundreds of years before Jesus was born prophesied that a baby would be born, in Bethlehem, of a virgin. There were over 50 more prophesies that were made about his life, and the sacrafice he made to pay for the sins of man, and the bigest one of all...He completely fufilled scripture when he rose from the dead. These men were inspired by Jesus, God, how can you argue that he is not the christ? The odds of one man filling all the prophesies is impossible. And these scriptures have been unchanged for the past 2000-2500 approx years! Thats proof for me that Jesus existed and that he is God. PM me if you like.

 
 The egyptians predicted his birth, death, WWI, WWII, and they have predict the supposed end of the world. Are you saying that this religion was wrong? They predicted a lot more that I have not put that have come true.
Valthonis

This statement is wrong. People from hundreds of years before Jesus was born prophesied that a baby would be born, in Bethlehem, of a virgin. There were over 50 more prophesies that were made about his life, and the sacrafice he made to pay for the sins of man, and the bigest one of all...He completely fufilled scripture when he rose from the dead. And these scriptures have been unchanged for the past 2000-2500 approx years! Thats proof for me that Jesus existed and that he is God. PM me if you like.

 
 I forgot to add something else. Some people in India that he did not actually die but he lived to be 86 years old. He was helped off of the cross. Are you saying that these people are wrong (they have a tomb there)
Lily

There HAS to be? Hmm... I don't think so. Why don't you go into it and spare us no details.

 
 If you insist...
 
 Let's say you go by Big Bang theory. Just because I actually believe it's true, to some extent. There were two "things" that bumped into each other, and the universe ensued. Yes, that makes sense to me. But where did they come from. The universe may have been formed from something as small as a fraction of a speck of dust. Maybe. Where'd the dust come from? How can there be nothing? Something must have been there. Something that made everything else. I like to call him "God."
 
 
You believe that Christianity is the 'One True Way.' And if it is... then it is. But your belief does not make it so. You believe Christianity is the one true way to live with God forever in heaven. However, this belief has underlying assumptions which are also beliefs, one of which is the assumption that God even exists. And if God exists, that God is like the God described in the Bible.

 
 You're 100% right. There's no way to be sure. What I believe is virtually useless. Unless I go out and kill a million people because of what I believe. That would be... er, bad. For lack of a better word.
 
 I don't believe you have to be Christian to get into heaven. I don't care what others say. I refuse to believe that a rabbi is going to hell. That's just... stupid.
 
 
These are things that can only be accepted through faith. It is not possible to KNOW these things... only to BELIEVE.

 
 Yes. I find it's quite more calming to believe in something, though. You have less a chance of going insane.
thebootfitter

Something that made everything else. I like to call him "God."

 Along these lines, then... who or what 'made' God? Your answer will likely be that God wasn't made, but always has existed, right? If God has always existed, why couldn't that 'speck of dust' always have existed?
Lily

Along these lines, then... who or what 'made' God? Your answer will likely be that God wasn't made, but always has existed, right? If God has always existed, why couldn't that 'speck of dust' always have existed?

 
 Because a speck of dust has no energy force. It can't "create itself." I'm not saying that God created himself, I'm saying that a speck of dust cannot spontaneously combust by its own will. It has no will.
 
 Nothing can create itself. There is no logical way that something can come from nothing without an outside force. There has to be something eternal.
emoreno2292

I like to call him "God." 
 Why does it have to be male? Or god?
 
 
 
 I don't believe you have to be Christian to get into heaven. I don't care what others say. I refuse to believe that a rabbi is going to hell. That's just... stupid. 

 Stupid or not, that's what the Bible says. It would seem that these days, people just pick and choose what they want to believe from the Bible. I understand that the Bible is able to be interpreted different ways, but people-- come on! It seems that people only believe what suits them instead of taking the whole thing as a package deal.
 
 
 
 Yes. I find it's quite more calming to believe in something, though. You have less a chance of going insane.

 Er, I don't quite understand this. Me and my voices here have been wondering what this means, but we haven't reached a conlcusion. Could you help us? ;)
Lily

Why does it have to be male? Or god?

 
 God has no gender. *shrug* If there's an infinite being of superior intelligence, that's pretty much my definition of "God." Call him what you like.
 
 
Stupid or not, that's what the Bible says. It would seem that these days, people just pick and choose what they want to believe from the Bible. I understand that the Bible is able to be interpreted different ways, but people-- come on! It seems that people only believe what suits them instead of taking the whole thing as a package deal.

 
 The Bible says:
 
 
From the Gospel According to John
 14:6 Jesus said to him, "I am the way, the truth, and the life. No one comes to the Father, except through me."

 
 Jesus died to save all people. He didn't pick and choose His followers. He loves us all, and some people just don't know any better.
 
 I'll also point out that in the first century, the entire Bible was rewritten to emphasize Ultimate Paternity. Who knows what else they changed? Quite frankly, I wouldn't put it past them.
 
 
Er, I don't quite understand this. Me and my voices here have been wondering what this means, but we haven't reached a conlcusion. Could you help us? ;)

 
 Sorry, that's my braincell's fault. It hasn't been in the mood for constructing coherent sentences lately.
 
 If you don't believe in something, then you believe in nothing. Which means that you trust nothing. Which means you don't trust yourself. If you can't trust yourself, who can you trust? No one. So you can't believe anything anyone says. Including what you say. So what you say isn't true. And then if you try to take back what you said that was wrong, you must be lying. Because you can't trust yourself.
 
 Just typing that made me feel dizzy. *wanders off to find ice pack*

title: 4Forums.com Political Debates and Polls -  Do you beleive God is Real? Why?
